oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Control of Stem Blight and the Spread of Potato Late Blight by Copper Seed Treatment
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Zellner, Michael
Keil, Sven
Benker, Marianne
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Crop health, quality, protection
Root crops
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Late blight still is an unsolved problem in organic potato farming. Up to now the most effective way to control this disease is the use of copper fungicides. Transferring results from regular farming, seed treatments with copper fungicides shall postpone the beginning of the blight epidemic and decrease the spread of the disease with soil water. Thus stem blight, which canâ€™t be prevented otherwise, shall be reduced. In field trials, conducted 2005-2007, copper fungicide treatments reduced primary stem infections (stem blight) and the spreading of the pathogen from infected seed tubers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: European Association for Potato Research, AV Zeist, The Netherlands
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Zellner, Michael; Keil, Sven and Benker, Marianne (2008) The Control of Stem Blight and the Spread of Potato Late Blight by Copper Seed Treatment. In: Abstracts of the 17th Triennial Conference of the European Association for Potato Research, European Association for Potato Research, AV Zeist, The Netherlands, pp. 294-296.
